data.text:
We are now deep into the â€œGreat Disney Depressionâ€ of the late seventies and eighties. This is an apt description for two reasons. Firstly, Disney are in a creative lull that has resulted in box office flops and reviews that arenâ€™t just sycophantic love letters. So, if the Disney-loving critics have concluded that recent films havenâ€™t been up to scratch, you can imagine how much Iâ€™ve detested them. Secondly, â€œdepressionâ€ is an ideal term because recent movies have been just that. Depressing. For me, â€˜The Rescuersâ€™ had bleak undertones, yet zero humour or warmth to balance it out. â€˜The Fox and The Houndâ€™ went one better and didnâ€™t just restrict the bleakness to its undertones. No Disney film prior had relentlessly felt so melancholy, and this is from the same company that brought you tales of attempted puppy-skinning. And Bambiâ€¦ And to top it off, last time out we had â€˜The Black Cauldronâ€™, where the deliberate upping of the â€˜dark and scaryâ€™ factor could have made it a memorable film for positive reasons, had it not been for the unfortunate obstacle of it being utterly crap.

Expectations then, are at possibly an all-time low coming into todayâ€™s film â€˜The Great Mouse Detectiveâ€™. Now, judging by the title, I have a gut feeling that this film will in some way involve a mouse, who is a detective. And is probably pretty good at it too. Just three films ago, we had the aforementioned â€˜The Rescuersâ€™, which also involved mice solving a mystery, and in about three films time, we will have â€˜The Rescuers Down Underâ€™. This leads me to believe that someone high-up at Disney HQ really gets their kicks from watching rodents solve shit. I just hope that this mouse is a lot more entertaining at doing his detective malarky than Bernard and Miss Bianca, possibly involving something that can actually raise a smile in the processâ€¦.

The film starts in London circa 1897. It must be London because this is an American film, and this scene depicts cobbled streets, horse and carts and church bells which is pretty much how Americans depict London even in the 21st century. We find ourselves at a toy shop called Flavershams where we meet a sweet little mouse called Olivia and her father, Mr Flaversham. They are very Scottish. Mice donâ€™t live very long so I find it very impressive that theyâ€™ve made it all the way from 19th century Scotland to London within their lifetime, let alone also having the time to set up a successful toy business once settledâ€¦. Mr Flaversham is giving Olivia a toy for her birthday. Sheâ€™s very happy. But trouble lies ahead, can you guess what? Correct! A bat with a wooden leg swoops in and kidnaps Mr Flaversham. This is definitely Disney. A cute mouse who has clearly already lost her mother now having to witness her Fatherâ€™s disappearance as well, resulting in her cries of â€œDaddy!â€ ringing out over the cityâ€¦ This sort of infant distress is bread and butter for the creative minds at chez-Disney. They must be moist with joy. Roll intro credits.

Next, we are introduced to a mouse who narrates with a VERY English accent. The Queens English obviously. Again, exactly how Americans always portray people in the UK. I wonder if he has a very posh English name? Heâ€™s called Dr David Q Dawson. Yes then. Plus, I imagine the Q stands for Quentin as I cannot think of any other male names beginning with Qâ€¦ He may wish that we refer to him as Dr David Q Dawson, but the reality is that down the pub, his mates call him Dave.

Dave finds Olivia crying. After explaining her predicament, Dave takes her to Baker Street to see Basil, the great mouse detective. Anyone who has seen the 1980â€™s British cartoon â€˜Dangermouseâ€™ will be sensing some dÃ©jÃ  vu around about now, as that also features a mouse on Baker Street that essentially rips off Sherlock Holmes. But of course, Disney will put its own inimitable stamp on this familiar scenario (less jokes and more frolicking animals with dead / wounded parents).

Initially Basil thinks itâ€™s an inappropriate time to help Olivia. What a dick. But once he realises that Mr Flaversham was taken by a bat with a wooden leg, he suddenly becomes interested. Not because the whyâ€™s and howâ€™s of a bat having a wooden leg (which would certainly arouse most peopleâ€™s interest), but because he works for the evil Professor Ratigan, Basilâ€™s arch enemy.

Letâ€™s meet this Ratigan then shall we? Ratigan must be pretty damn awesome. How do I know this? Because a load of rodents declare this in a song. You donâ€™t take the time to learn a song and dance routine unless youâ€™re really invested in the lyrics youâ€™re singing. He must be GREAT. Not only that, heâ€™s also quite entertaining. Ok, so he feeds one of his drunken mouse lackeys to his pet cat (no, Iâ€™m not sure how a rat successfully has a pet cat either) because he was drunk and annoying, but thereâ€™s been far more irritating baddies than this. Of course he still possesses that typical Disney antagonist trait of revelling in doing evil things just because theyâ€™re evil, rather than the more realistic â€˜doing bad shit thatâ€™s self-serving and/or mean and justifying itâ€™s the right thing to do usually because of some self-entitlement, prejudice or pleasing some deityâ€™.

Ratigan has a â€œdiabolicalâ€ scheme. Basically this scheme involves kidnapping the queen and replacing her with a mechanical version that will declare Ratigan the king. Iâ€™m quite liking this plan, but more for the ingenuity than the actual questionable logic that it could work. So Mr Flaversham was kidnapped, it turns out, so that he would make this mechanical toy version of the Queen. Why is he doing this dastardly deed? Because if he doesnâ€™t, some bad shit will happen to Olivia. Oh Ratigan you scoundrel.

Speaking of Olivia, she wants to go on the journey to upend the bad guys. Basil says no but she accompanies him and Dave anyway. By using Sherlock Holmes dog to sniff out where the Bat (who is called Fidget, apparently) has gone, they wind up in a toy shop where they discover Fidget trying to get parts to make the fake queen. Unfortunately, in what could only be described as a colossal fuck up, Fidget not only gets away, but also manages to kidnap Olivia in the process.

Now, it may seem that I have a very good handle on the storyline at this point. But that is a lie. The truth is that whilst watching the first half of the film, I didnâ€™t. Hereâ€™s the thing, I find it quite difficult to concentrate at the best of times, but during Disney films I find I become even more easily distracted than usual. On top of that, Disney seems to have a habit of mentioning key plot points just once and then never addressing them again. Fortunately, the Disney fandom site provides a good synopsis to fill the moments that my mind goes a wondering. I also thankfully found this less of a problem during the films second half, as the pace picks up and generally more stuff happensâ€¦

Basil finds a note containing the list of things Fidget was stealing from the toy shop. He does some detective shit to discover it was written where the sewage system meets the river. So he and Dave go to a bar there, disguised as sailors. Itâ€™s a proper dive full of rough sorts who hurl abuse at the entertainment (in this case, a juggling octopus). I then wrote in my notes, â€œI suppose the cabaret is a juggling octopus, as the usual entertainment in a dive like that in that era would be a sexy burlesque dancer, and they couldnâ€™t have that in a Disney film!!!â€. But then out comes the singing mouse and her dancersâ€¦. If I was surprised at the sexy manner in which the mouse sings, I was even more shook at the partial striptease and sultriness of the dancing. Obviously not sexy enough to get a semi or anything. Itâ€™s a cartoon mouse and no-one gets a semi at a cartoon mouse, so stop talking about it. No-one got a semi, agreed? Good.

After spotting fidget, Basil and Dave enquire about â€œtheir old friendâ€ Ratigan. It would seem that they were too obvious however, as Dave gets his drink spiked. In his daze, he jumps up on stage to join in with the dancing burlesque mice that caused no-one to become inappropriately aroused. In the confusion, Fidget escapes, but Basil and Dave follow him through the sewage pipes to Ratigan HQ. But alas, it is a trap. Ratigan is waiting for their arrival.

He decides to dispose of the heroes in true Bond movie villain style. Instead of a quick murder, perhaps involving the pet cat, he instead ties them up. And a whole series of murderous weapons will be triggered in the style of the game â€˜Mouse Trapâ€™, by a string that will only tighten enough to start the fucktitude of chaos once the arm of the record player itâ€™s attached to reaches the end of the song Ratigan has written about his victory over Basil. Thatâ€™s right thereâ€™s a song.

So think about this: Instead of taking 3 seconds to shoot them in the face, in the time that Ratigan knew that Basil would be attempting to infiltrate his hideout, he instead did the following: First he went to a hardware shop. There he would have bought all the materials needed to make the various weapons of mouse destruction. Then he would have to have gone on the black market no doubt to obtain a few of the more nefarious instruments required. Then, he and his team would have to laboriously set up the â€˜mouse trapâ€™ style mechanism. Next, he would have to go to the trouble of writing a song (or putting an ad out to hire a songwriter to compose some music for him), then writing the lyrics that brag about his victory. Then he would have had to have hired a studio (in those days home studios were unheard of, especially among the rat community). Then he would have needed at least a sixteen-piece orchestra to perform the piece, assuming Ratigan had scored out all the parts for the hired hands. Then he would need to mix the resulting song. Following this, he had to have the track printed onto vinyl. I truly admire the trouble Ratigan went to in order to make the most entertaining murdering device possible. Now this is a proper antagonist. And the resulting song, genuinely made me laugh. My concentration had been wavering throughout the film before this point, but this bit came as close to winning me over as anything else Iâ€™ve seen Disney churn out, strangely arousing burlesque mice includedâ€¦

Ratigan is now free to kidnap the queen and put a toy replica in her place. Mr Flaversham is forced to control this toy queen. She announces that Ratigan will be the new ruler over the rodent world. Now the only way this calamity can be rectified is with a Disney trope checklist to ensure all things end the way we have come to expect:

Daring escape from near certain doom for our heroes? âœ…

Stopping the bad guy in the nick of time? âœ…

Overblown chase scene? âœ…

The moment the bad guy meets his demise it seems like the hero is a goner too, only to for the scriptwriters to go â€œgotcha! Heâ€™s fine, lolâ€? âœ…

They all lived happily ever after (except for the bad guy who drowns if the impact of falling from a great height hasnâ€™t already turned his insides to smithereens)? âœ…

The end.

So was it a classic film? No. But hereâ€™s the thing: I didnâ€™t mind it too much. Maybe itâ€™s because my expectations were so low, especially following â€˜The Black Cauldronâ€™. Maybe itâ€™s because my lasting memories of the film were Ratiganâ€™s song and burlesque mice that DEFINITELY didnâ€™t cause a semi. Iâ€™ve seen people suggest it was the worst ever Disney film, as well as people who have a soft spot for it. The film saved Disney from bankruptcy, but on the plus side, it apparently triggered an upturn in the quality of future the â€˜Animated Studiosâ€™ films, so fingers crossed on that one. Overall, I think this film feels a lot more classically â€˜Disneyâ€™ then many of the recent films. The film ends with Dave discussing how after their success, he joined Basil for many more adventures, just like Watson did with Sherlock Holmes. A reminder that â€˜The Great Mouse Detectiveâ€™ is an adaptation of the book â€˜The Great Mouse Detectiveâ€™. Which is an adaptation. Of â€˜Sherlock Holmesâ€™. Frolicking orphan animals and near-death chase scenes aside, it doesnâ€™t get more Disney than that.

6/10

That song by Ratigan was one of the funniest things Iâ€™ve seen in a Disney film in ages! Just needed to express that from the start.

I had seen parts of The Great Mouse Detective in the past, but never the whole film and I have to say, I really enjoyed it. I think Benâ€™s covered my thoughts in his review.

I will add that we have ONE more film until The Little Mermaid!!!!! Iâ€™m gonna try and convince Ben to watch Oliver and Company this evening, but Iâ€™m not gonna hold my breath.

6/10 (also)
